title: Boy, 3, with autism thrown out of shop for having assistance dog
text:
Little Leon Bulner was turned away with his dad Karsten because he had an assistance dog with him (Picture: Ryan Evans/Andover Advertiser/Google)

A family was left ‘humiliated’ after their young son who has autism was turned away from a shop because he had his assistance dog with him.

Three-year-old Leon Bulner and dad Karsten visited a Londis store with two-year-old dog Fern but said they were told the animal was not allowed in after two ‘disgusting’ exchanges.

When Mr Bulner tried to explain that his son has moderate to severe autism, he said the cashier at the store in Hampshire village Weyhill, near Andover, told him ‘no dogs, end of’.

After going back the following day to explain the situation to the manager, he added that he was ‘basically thrown out’ and told that only dogs for blind or deaf people were allowed.

He retorted that the shop wasn’t following the law, but Mr Bulner said the staff member replied that it was ‘Londis law’ and that he ‘didn’t care’ about a potential fine.

The store’s parent company has since apologised and said they will update their policies.

The family were turned away for having little Fern with them, who calms down the three-year-old (Picture: Ryan Evans/Andover Advertiser)

Describing the experience as ‘humiliating, embarrassing and disgusting’, Mr Bulner said: ‘I’m trying to keep my cool and bite my tongue, but to be treated like that is unbelievable.

‘It’s disability discrimination. You’re basically saying if you’re not blind then you can’t bring any assistance dog in here.’

The father said they are regularly challenged when they bring Fern into establishments but once people realise the dog’s purpose, they tend not to face further issues.

But Mr Bulner, who wants to raise awareness of ‘invisible disabilities’, continued: ‘That’s how it should be.

‘The dog gets him out of this stage where he goes into a meltdown and nobody can do it better than the dog.

The incident occurred at a Londis in Andover (Picture: Google)

‘(Fern has) changed his life completely.’

Vas Mohanathas, area manager for JP&S Services, the company who run the store, said in a letter to Mr Bulner: ‘I am appalled at the way this was handled by the staff on site.

‘I have forwarded the videos to the director and discussed my concerns with him. Please take assurance in knowing that he feels the same way about this as you and I and has asked me to action the investigation and staff training immediately.’

He added that a new sign saying ‘assistance dogs allowed’ had been ordered and that the company will add a local guide dog trust to the charities they support.

The manager added that staff will give free dog treats to guide and assistance dogs that visit the store.

description: Leon Bulner, 3, told that assistance dog Fern can't come inside store near Andover because it is 'Londis law'.
